title: Beth Run
text:
Beth Run is a <a href="tributary">tributary</a> of <a href="Bowman%20Creek">Bowman Creek</a> in <a href="Luzerne%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Luzerne County, Pennsylvania</a>, in the United States. It is approximately long and flows through <a href="Ross%20Township%2C%20Luzerne%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Ross Township</a> and <a href="Lake%20Township%2C%20Luzerne%20County%2C%20Pennsylvania">Lake Township</a>. The watershed of the stream has an area of . The surficial geology along it consists of Wisconsinan Till and alluvium. The stream's watershed is designated as a High-Quality Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery and the stream is <a href="Class%20A%20Wild%20Trout%20Waters">Class A Wild Trout Waters</a>.
Course.
Beth Run begins at the head of a valley in Ross Township. It flows east-northeast for several tenths of a mile before turning northeast for several tenths of a mile and entering Lake Township. Here, the stream receives an unnamed tributary from the <a href="wikt%3Aright%20bank">right</a> and turns north for several tenths of a mile, its valley widening considerably. At the end of the valley, the stream reaches its confluence with Bowman Creek.
Beth Run joins Bowman Creek upstream of its mouth.
Hydrology.
The concentration of <a href="alkalinity">alkalinity</a> in Beth Run is .
Geography and geology.
The elevation near the <a href="river%20mouth">mouth</a> of Beth Run is above <a href="sea%20level">sea level</a>. The elevation of the stream's <a href="river%20source">source</a> between above sea level.
The <a href="surficial%20geology">surficial geology</a> along most of the length of Beth Run consists of a <a href="till">till</a> known as <a href="Wisconsinan%20Till">Wisconsinan Till</a>. In the stream's upper reaches, <a href="alluvium">alluvium</a> is present as well and some of the Wisconsinan Till is underlain by <a href="glacial%20lake">glacial lake</a> clays. There is also a patch of Wisconsinan Bouldery Till at the headwaters; it is rich in <a href="boulder">boulder</a>s. The surficial geology along the sides of the stream's valley includes <a href="bedrock">bedrock</a> consisting of <a href="sandstone">sandstone</a> and <a href="shale">shale</a>.
Watershed.
The <a href="drainage%20basin">watershed</a> of Beth Run has an area of . The stream is entirely within the <a href="United%20States%20Geological%20Survey">United States Geological Survey</a> <a href="quadrangle%20%28geography%29">quadrangle</a> of Sweet Valley.
The entire length of Beth Run is on public land that is open to access.
History.
Beth Run was entered into the <a href="Geographic%20Names%20Information%20System">Geographic Names Information System</a> on August 2, 1979. Its identifier in the Geographic Names Information System is 1169332.
In the 1970s, the <a href="Pennsylvania%20Game%20Commission">Pennsylvania Game Commission</a> was attempting to purchase a tract of land in the vicinity of Beth Run to add to <a href="Pennsylvania%20State%20Game%20Lands%20Number%2057">Pennsylvania State Game Lands Number 57</a>. The Pennsylvania Game Commission also once requested a permit to construct an aluminum <a href="box%20culvert">box culvert</a> bridge over the stream with the purpose of providing access to the southern parts of <a href="Pennsylvania%20State%20Game%20Lands%20Number%2057">Pennsylvania State Game Lands Number 57</a> for tree salvage cutting.
Biology.
The drainage basin of Beth Run is designated as a High-Quality Coldwater Fishery and a Migratory Fishery. Wild <a href="trout">trout</a> naturally reproduce in the stream from its headwaters downstream to its mouth. It is classified by the <a href="Pennsylvania%20Fish%20and%20Boat%20Commission">Pennsylvania Fish and Boat Commission</a> as Class A Wild Trout Waters for <a href="brook%20trout">brook trout</a> from its headwaters downstream to its mouth.
